p:
Late-onset sporadic forms of neurodegenerative diseases are devastating conditions imposing an increasing burden on healthcare systems worldwide. Currently, 2–3% of the population over 65 years of age are living with Parkinson’s disease (PD), making this disorder the most prevalent late-onset neurodegenerative disorder worldwide after Alzheimer’s disease.
1 This progressive condition is characterised by the loss of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta manifesting clinically as a tremor at rest, muscle rigidity and bradykinesia.
1, 2 Existing symptomatic treatments do not alter the course of the disease and their effectiveness declines with time, which makes the identification of potential therapeutic targets of key importance.
